headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Hoover, Chief Executive Officer. Please go ahea
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Hoover, Chief Executive Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's conference call regarding the company's fourth quarter and full year 2009 results. The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or
componenttext: Thank you, Sean, and good morning, everyone. This is Ball Corporation's conference call regarding the company's fourth quarter and full year 2009 results. The information provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes may differ materially from those that may be expressed or implied. Some factors that could cause the results or outcomes to differ are in the company's latest 10-Q and in other company SEC filings, as well as company news releases. And if you don't already have our earnings release, it's available on our website at ball.com. Information regarding the use of non-GAAP financial measures may also be found on our website.Ball finished 2009 on a strong note. Fourth quarter comparable earnings per share of $0.84 versus $0.56 last year increased by 50%. Also on a comparable basis, our diluted earnings per share were $4.05 in 2009 versus $3.61 in 2008, a 12% improvement. Our businesses are performing well. Nearly every segment saw month-on-month volume improvement during 2009. We're executing on our strategy to grow our Global Beverage Can business and our strong free cash flow long-term relationships with the customers and sound balance sheet position us to build on our momentum in 2010 and beyond.2010 marks Ball's 130th year in business and we're going to work hard to make sure it's our best year ever. With me on today's call are John Hayes, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Scott Morrison, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and also joining us is Ray Seabrook. In November we announced that John, Scott and Ray were being promoted. Though Ray has been our CFO for a decade he's always had an affinity for our operations and now in his role as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Global Packaging. He has operating responsibility for 90% of Ball's businesses.Both today and in the future Scott will interpret our numbers, we thought the investor community should not be cut off cold turkey from Ray, so we invited Ray to be on the call today and before Scott and John discuss the quarter, Ray, would you like to greet the group?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Thanks, Dave. Gee, a decade sound like a long time. Anyway, I'm excited about my new position with the company and getting more involved with the day-to-day operations. John, Scott and I have worked closely together over the past 10 years and
componenttext: Absolutely. Thanks, Dave. Gee, a decade sound like a long time. Anyway, I'm excited about my new position with the company and getting more involved with the day-to-day operations. John, Scott and I have worked closely together over the past 10 years and from my perspective the transition to our new jobs has gone smoothly. Scott, Dave and I as the past two CFOs of the company turn over the conference call range to you and I might add we turn it over with you with record 2009 results and a plan four at least $0.5 billion of free cash flow in 2010. So with that, take it away, Scott.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Ray. With that kind of lead and what can I say, other than that, big shoes to fill but I'm confident  that our finance team is up to the challenge. Ray has set a great example of what a CFO should be and I'm excited about the opportunity to follow
componenttext: Thanks Ray. With that kind of lead and what can I say, other than that, big shoes to fill but I'm confident  that our finance team is up to the challenge. Ray has set a great example of what a CFO should be and I'm excited about the opportunity to follow him and get to know in all of you on the call better. In the fourth quarter, Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share were up $0.84 well ahead of last year's $0.56. Overall, the fourth quarter numbers were very strong due to the excellent performance in Metal Beverage Packaging, Americas and Asia, a better than expected contribution from the newly acquired container plant, a stronger euro and excellent fixed cost controls in European beverage, and an overall, lower effective tax rate.Turning to the operating segments. Metal Beverage Americas and Asia had improved earnings for the quarter and the year, a better than expected contribution from the metal container plant, cost savings resulting from prior plant rationalization and lower fixed cost all provided good earnings momentum in the quarter. Metal Beverage Europe's earnings were up considerably for the quarter due to the impact of a higher euro and lower fixed cost. Full year lower earnings were primarily related to the full year exchange impact and product mix.Metal food and household product earnings in the quarter were down due to the lower volumes and the favorable resolution of a $6.8 million claim recorded in the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year, earnings were up considerably due to inventory holding gain improved margins and benefits prior plant rationalization efforts, which more than offset the double-digit volume declines in the segment.Plastics was profitable in the fourth quarter versus break-even results last year. Full year EBIT improved slightly despite an 11% reduction in volume. Aerospace and Technologies posted near double-digit EBIT margins in the quarter despite lower sales. The absence of large fixed price hardware contracts was the primary reason for the decline in year-over-year revenue and earnings. A higher euro in the quarter compared to last year increased diluted share earnings by $0.04 and for the year, the impact of a lower euro was negative impact of $0.03 per diluted share compared to 2008.Turning to full year free cash flow. Ball generated $373 million, which was on target with our expectations. That included an incremental $14 million pension contribution and an investment in working capital totaling $82 million which was slightly larger than our earlier estimate of $70 million as we took advantage of early payment discounts. The working capital build is expected to largely to reverse in 2010.As Ray indicated would be the case, the cash collateral of the company was required to post with counter parties in 2008 was returned by the end of 2009. Net balance sheet debt at the end of the year was approximately $2.4 billion, only $100 million higher than the net balance sheet debt at the end of 2008. Despite making a nearly $600 million acquisition during 2009.Credit quality and liquidity of the company remains solid with the 2009 rolling four quarters EBIT to interest coverage at 5.6x and net debt to EBITDA at 2.5x. Committed credit and available liquidity at year end was in excess of $800 million.As we look to full year 2010 earnings and cash flow, we anticipate capital spending in the range of $235 million. CapEx will remain at these disciplined levels until we see growth opportunities returning.  Free cash flow should be in excess of $0.5 billion, excluding the impact of a change in how we account for our AR securitization program, which I'll cover in a minute. Pension expenses projected to be about $6 million higher in 2010 while after-tax pension funding is expected to be approximately $25 million lower.The full year effective tax rate will likely increase to around 33% due to projected higher U.S. earnings as a result of the full year impact of our Metal Beverage acquisition as the U.S. is our highest tax jurisdiction. With the full year impact of the additional debt for our acquisition, we expect 2010 interest expense in the range of $140 million. We also expect to improve our already strong balance sheet in 2010 by having plenty of flexibility to great value for our shareholders.Also want to get ahead of the curve and address an item before we get to our first quarter earnings announcement. Due to the issuance of revised guidance on the accounting for AR securitization programs effective in the first quarter of 2010, the aspects [ph] of how free cash flow will look in 2010 needs to be addressed. The accounting change will result in our securitization being placed on the balance sheet. We have had a securitization since the 1990s and have consistently reported the outstanding amount during conference calls and in financial statement footnotes. While 2009 year on AR securitization balance was $250 million, the maximum level of the plan. The change will be reflected in the first quarter 10-Q and subsequent periods for any outstanding securitization balance. And in the first year, the effect will be to increase accounts receivable and debt on the balance sheet.While the net balance sheet and cash flow affected zero, the change will create a one-time reduction in operating cash flow for the amount of receivables securitized and an offsetting increase in cash inflows from financing activities. We will break out the impacts so that you will be able to see the net change and comparability between periods. It is fewer than accounting change but I wanted to point it out now so you'll be aware of the change and with that, I'll turn it over to John.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. As Ray mentioned, all of us have been working together for a number of years and like every good team, we're able to feed off each other. We have complementary skill sets, a talented bench of people across the organization and wonderful
componenttext: Thank you, Scott. As Ray mentioned, all of us have been working together for a number of years and like every good team, we're able to feed off each other. We have complementary skill sets, a talented bench of people across the organization and wonderful base from which to continue building needless to say all of us are geared to go here at Ball Corp. We did have a strong year in 2009 and we are teed up for better 2010 and beyond. Better supply and demand balance, good focus on cost management, a disciplined approach to our commercial activities and continued focus on market leadership, and sustainability and innovation helped drive our 2009 performance.Now turning to the various businesses. Profitability for the quarter in our Metal Beverage Packaging, Americas and Asia segment was slightly above our expectations and notably improved over 2008. This was driven largely by improving volume dynamics late in the fourth quarter. Cost containment in this business remains excellent and continued cost savings from plant rationalizations contributed to improved results. Excluding the newly acquired facilities, our fourth quarter volume in North America was down approximately 3% versus a decline of 1% for the industry. However, our volumes improved month by month in the quarter and our December results were some of the strongest that we've seen in a while. Driving this was stronger promotional activity of our customers in the CSD side, as they balanced the value to volume equation, and continued packet share increases in the beer side of  the business.Volumes in our newly acquired facilities also experienced similar demand trends.At year-end Ball also successfully concluded negotiations on all of our significant Metal Beverage contracts. Our customer conversations were constructive and we are satisfied with the results of these negotiations. With the acquisition of the former metal container plants in North America, we have the opportunity to take a fresh look at our customer mix and we use this opportunity to balance our customer concentration. Given the size of our business, this often can take a couple of years to accomplish and as a result we may step back slightly in 2010 in terms of overall volume while recovering it in 2011 and beyond.In Asia, Paul announced in November its intention to acquired the remaining 65% interest in JFP's Sanshui facility. Once completed, this facility will provide Ball an opportunity to better serve our customer base in Southern China and provides us a low-cost way of increasing our capacity without growing overall industry capacity.In summary, we expect 2010 profitability in the Americas, Asia segment to be improved driven by contribution of three additional quarters of the two acquisitions, continued cost savings resulting from the previous announced capacity closures, continued focus on our cost optimization initiatives and continued growth from new innovative product launches like Alumi-Tek and a 7.5 ounce 90-calorie soft drink can. This will be slightly offset by planned lower volumes in North America.In our European operations, volumes improved slightly for the full year with volumes roughly flat year-over-year in the fourth quarter. A stronger euro and cost saving initiatives implemented in the plants offset continued negative product mix. With 33-centiliter CSD growth, offsetting lower 50-centiliter beer sales. However, we have seen Eastern Europe, excluding Russia stabilized and Western Europe continues to hold up reasonably well particularly in France and the Netherlands.As we look towards 2010, the overall pricing dynamics in Europe are a bit more challenging than in prior years due to the supply demand balance. However, our European management team continues to monitor the demand trends by region and stands ready to adjust to any deviations to our expectations. Our continued FX tailwinds and mitigating cost inputs will help to offset weaker price mix, as in the Americas and Asia segment, we expect earnings improvement in 2010 in this segment as well. Our Food and Household product group performed very well in 2009, excellent execution on our rationalization program, tight discipline around our pricing and cost recovery initiatives and overall attention to detail and focused execution contributed to strong performance. Fourth quarter year-over-year performance was off mainly due to a favorable resolution of a $6.8 million claim collected in the fourth quarter of 2008 and difficult volume comps from the prior year. Recall fourth quarter 2008 volumes were up 4% due to a pre-buy of food and aerosol packaging that impacted the entire industry. Aerosol volumes continue to improve at year-end but still finished the year down more than 10%.As Scott mentioned, first quarter 2010 comparisons in this segment will be negative as a result to the first quarter 2009 inventory holding gains. Plastic Packaging Americas had a challenging fourth quarter driven primarily by lower volumes in the CSD and Water segments. Overall volumes were down in the low teens and we took additional downtime in the fourth quarter to manage inventory targets. However, our Food Plastic customer base experienced improved trends especially in the smaller category of Nutriceuticals. Our Aerospace business had a strong fourth quarter with sales and EBIT both exceeding our internal expectations. Our antenna, components and service businesses are maintaining good growth trajectory and management is awaiting word on a number of bids to enhance the backlog and position the business for growth going forward.We are pleased with the operational performance of our company but we are not content. 2010 will be a year where we continue to make further progress on the initiatives underway, we're focusing on best practice sharing and plant efficiencies across our worldwide system and the continued execution of our overall strategy. And with that, I'll turn it back to Dave.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John and thank you, Scott and you Ray for your comments. The Ball Corporation is performing very well. Our strategy is clear, the balance sheet is strong and our strong free cash flow provides flexibility to generate value creation for our shareho
componenttext: Thanks, John and thank you, Scott and you Ray for your comments. The Ball Corporation is performing very well. Our strategy is clear, the balance sheet is strong and our strong free cash flow provides flexibility to generate value creation for our shareholders. I'm optimistic about 2010 and the longer-term prospects for our business. The company certainly expects full year 2010 results to improve over those of last year. And with that Sean, I believe we're ready for questions.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's encouraging to see that you've seen a bit of a pick up in your beverage Americas volume. Dave or John or Ray, if you could comment at all, how the tone of dialogue has changed perhaps with your customers regarding promotion into the new year? What so
componenttext: It's encouraging to see that you've seen a bit of a pick up in your beverage Americas volume. Dave or John or Ray, if you could comment at all, how the tone of dialogue has changed perhaps with your customers regarding promotion into the new year? What sorts of trends they expect and how that varies with what you were seeing last year at this time? And then similarly, in food cans, can you comment at all in terms of the relative, it's early in the year particularly for food cans but what the tone of dialogue is with your customers about their expectations for volume and promotion.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the CSD side, if you go back 12 months ago, the overall, CSD segment was really focusing on pricing over volume. And you could clearly see it in all the IRI numbers. As you got to the fourth quarter of last year, you started to see those trends reverse
componenttext: On the CSD side, if you go back 12 months ago, the overall, CSD segment was really focusing on pricing over volume. And you could clearly see it in all the IRI numbers. As you got to the fourth quarter of last year, you started to see those trends reverse and you saw a lot of promotional activity and they're really focusing on trying to get the volumes going through price promotions. And again, if you look at the IRI data over the last four weeks or eight weeks of the quarter, you'll clearly able to see that. As we go into 2010, I think the customer base is still trying to figure out this value versus volume equation. And while we don't have very strong expectations that they are going to push real hard, it's too early in the year to tell. We do have the Winter Olympics coming up. We have the World Cup over in Europe. So I think some of the promotional activity around that will be telling.  Turning to the food side, I think the tone overall, is relatively constructive. There wasn't destocking in the first half of the year last year that's why I believe volumes were a bit soft. They started to improve in the fourth quarter and as we go into 2010 we're starting to see some volume trends are much more constructive than they certainly were 12 months ago.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, within your key products, beverage cans and/or food cans, are you seeing any increased level of threat from substitution and if there is, how would it vary by geography? And then on the pricing and supply dynamic in Europe, can you give us an update
componenttext: One, within your key products, beverage cans and/or food cans, are you seeing any increased level of threat from substitution and if there is, how would it vary by geography? And then on the pricing and supply dynamic in Europe, can you give us an update in terms on how that trend has evolved? And what sort of operating rate you think you might be at, really it's hard to say, in January in 2010 in Europe?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the substitution issue, you go around the world actually, the beverage can is doing reasonably well. I mentioned here in North America on the beer side, it's been gaining share in the packaged mix. I think in 2000 -- when the financial crisis hit in la
componenttext: On the substitution issue, you go around the world actually, the beverage can is doing reasonably well. I mentioned here in North America on the beer side, it's been gaining share in the packaged mix. I think in 2000 -- when the financial crisis hit in late 2008 you didn't see in Eastern Europe, for example, a decline of the can on a relative basis to overall beer volumes. We're starting to see a little bit of a recovery and in fact I believe in the full fourth quarter, Generally speaking, as I said Eastern Europe, you exclude Russia and there was actually a little bit of growth in some of those major markets there. I think overall, the can is holding up pretty well in this overall, environment. We have expectations that these trend will continue because of the convenience of the can and because of the wonderful sustainability aspects of it. With respect to your question about efficiencies and supply and demand in Europe, we are running pretty tight. As you recall, we had plans to get going on our Lublin, Poland facility and we have put those on indefinite hold because we don't need to be making cans for practice and we expect to be pretty tight in 2010 from an efficiency point of view but there's been other capacity additions in the industry and I think that's what I was alluding to.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: Yes, in fact, Ghansham, in all of our businesses in North America we took downtime that was greater than, we have in past years because as we said we are going to be running with business for cash and we don't need to throw a bunch of excess inventory around our balance sheet.

componenttext: Yes, we had an awful lot of activities to share best practices across the facility. They're wonderful facilities as ours and we can be learning from each other and so we have very detailed plans on how to make sure we're maximizing the most out of both systems.

componenttext: There have been a couple of companies out there that mentioned they saw some customers maybe push some volumes back from the fourth quarter into the first quarter, I was wondering if you saw anything like that if you saw customers deferring volume to diminish cash?

componenttext: I don't think so. I certainly haven't heard of that.

componenttext: We haven't heard nor seen it.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Broadly speaking, what's the tone of your customers like? Did they seem to be expecting some improvement here in the near term or what's the outlook from their perspective?
componenttext: Broadly speaking, what's the tone of your customers like? Did they seem to be expecting some improvement here in the near term or what's the outlook from their perspective?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The people I've been around or talked with, I'm thinking in food cans, some in the beer and beverage business I think it can vary from customer to customer but generally more optimistic. We're all looking for green shoots or whatever it is for the economy
componenttext: The people I've been around or talked with, I'm thinking in food cans, some in the beer and beverage business I think it can vary from customer to customer but generally more optimistic. We're all looking for green shoots or whatever it is for the economy but if you think about our business, it doesn't fluctuate as many do. And the best sign we have is how we performed in the fourth quarter I think. We're a reflection of what our customers are doing. But certainly as John mentioned earlier, for example, the destocking in food, people have lived on their pantries for a period of time. One of our good food customers told me that they're absolutely certain that's what happened. You might have seen I think it was in yesterday's Wall Street Journal they talked about the bullwhip effect and they were mentioning I think Caterpillar specifically whose ordering lots more from their customers and so on and so forth because they ran their inventories down so far that even if they don't expect sales improvement they've got to start building. And lead times and so forth. If that does begin to happen, that ought to improve economic activity and it ought improve the sales of our customers.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you go outside of the United States, in the fourth quarter in Europe, our volumes actually were up in the quarter if you exclude the export sales. Our export sales were down a little bit having to do with various issues but our fourth quarter in what t
componenttext: If you go outside of the United States, in the fourth quarter in Europe, our volumes actually were up in the quarter if you exclude the export sales. Our export sales were down a little bit having to do with various issues but our fourth quarter in what they would describe as Western and Eastern Europe excluding Russia,they were up. You go down into Brazil and we're seeing very strong continued growth down there and go into China, and you see beverage growth still in the strong double-digit. There was destocking in the first half of last year and I think we're starting to get some of it back.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: I don't think that we do. I think certainly we feel that we ought to be able to achieve over the time and the amounts that we indicated hopefully it will be better. It's pretty fast though it gets hard to really track that. We are going to operate as one system and as John said earlier, thought I think we are optimistic that there is maybe more to do than we estimated.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, let's start in Europe, since we're kind of talking around that area. As you look into 2010, you're starting to see some improved volume trajectory it sounds like out of your core Europe Eastern, Western, you think it's reasonable as we look
componenttext: First of all, let's start in Europe, since we're kind of talking around that area. As you look into 2010, you're starting to see some improved volume trajectory it sounds like out of your core Europe Eastern, Western, you think it's reasonable as we look out over the next 12 months to anticipate kind of mid single-digit volume growth over there again?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: To be quite honest, Chris it's too early to tell. We do have some tailwind in terms of the destocking we mentioned that was a global issue, as well as the World Cup which was generally in the same time zone as Europe and that's a big deal over there. But
componenttext: To be quite honest, Chris it's too early to tell. We do have some tailwind in terms of the destocking we mentioned that was a global issue, as well as the World Cup which was generally in the same time zone as Europe and that's a big deal over there. But to be honest, I just think it's too early to say what the volume expectations are. We can tell you that CSD has been performing better than beer. But I think with the World Cup as I said you're going to see a lot of beer promotional activity all through Western and Eastern Europe.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I looked at operating performance over there in EBIT dollars, you were off a little bit this year and I think most of that throughout the year is probably currency related. But even in cyclical [ph]   environment it sounds like you did really well on
componenttext: When I looked at operating performance over there in EBIT dollars, you were off a little bit this year and I think most of that throughout the year is probably currency related. But even in cyclical [ph]   environment it sounds like you did really well on getting some costs out of the system at the end of the year. Would there be any reason to expect that you wouldn't continue to see some growth in at least in the profit side in Europe next year.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we sit here today that's what our expectations are and what we've been trying to do not only in Europe, but across our businesses that -- as you all know, we're a fixed cost business, and we get a lot of operating leverage as volumes start to return, a
componenttext: As we sit here today that's what our expectations are and what we've been trying to do not only in Europe, but across our businesses that -- as you all know, we're a fixed cost business, and we get a lot of operating leverage as volumes start to return, and so we've dropped -- been trying to position ourselves for the worse. And if volume expectations come back, we've got a lot of leverage there.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last question I have was usage of cash in 2010, with your credit stats back to essentially pre-deal and you still have nine months of that to roll through your numbers yet, so it will look even better, how would you prioritize uses of free cash? Do yo
componenttext: The last question I have was usage of cash in 2010, with your credit stats back to essentially pre-deal and you still have nine months of that to roll through your numbers yet, so it will look even better, how would you prioritize uses of free cash? Do you think about dividends? Do you think about more share repurchase? Are there areas out to acquire that look attractive to you? How do you think about that balance, John?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Scott. I think we look at all of those things. We have -- the focus is on generating free cash flow. We think, this year, it's in excess of $500,000,000. We have $250 million of term loan payments to make this year, so that leaves quite a bit of e
componenttext: This is Scott. I think we look at all of those things. We have -- the focus is on generating free cash flow. We think, this year, it's in excess of $500,000,000. We have $250 million of term loan payments to make this year, so that leaves quite a bit of extra. And we look at share purchase, we look at dividends and we look at acquisitions. So whatever the opportunity that presents itself.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if there's anyway to just help us get a little clear on what that volume adjustment in North America and bev can may look like in 2010, assuming that sort of overall industry volumes are flattish.
componenttext: I wonder if there's anyway to just help us get a little clear on what that volume adjustment in North America and bev can may look like in 2010, assuming that sort of overall industry volumes are flattish.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it will be down a little bit. It's too early to tell you. You said assuming volumes are flattish. It's going to be down a little bit, but not wholesale. So don't read into that at all. It's just -- as we said is, if there's a balancing effect going o
componenttext: Yes, it will be down a little bit. It's too early to tell you. You said assuming volumes are flattish. It's going to be down a little bit, but not wholesale. So don't read into that at all. It's just -- as we said is, if there's a balancing effect going on, you have to do it over a multiyear. So we'll take a slight step back in 2010 and make it up in 2011.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I could, the Plastics business, just any more thoughts on kind of further initiatives you could take there beyond the closures that you've announced to improve the performance in that business.
componenttext: And then if I could, the Plastics business, just any more thoughts on kind of further initiatives you could take there beyond the closures that you've announced to improve the performance in that business.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's been a challenging time when you point [ph] volumes are off. I give our folks a lot credit with volumes off as much as they were in that slide [ph] earnings year-over-year. It's gotten to the point where it really depends on what's going on in the ma
componenttext: It's been a challenging time when you point [ph] volumes are off. I give our folks a lot credit with volumes off as much as they were in that slide [ph] earnings year-over-year. It's gotten to the point where it really depends on what's going on in the marketplace, some of the specialty stuff. We've seen some good growth as I mentioned, not only in the nutraceuticals, but just generally, on the heat set, we do some wine business, other things like that. So we just had some good growth and some profitable growth to offset the cold fill side of the business, but we're spending a lot of time looking at how we can play that in a way that we can make money.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Meanwhile, we're reducing the investment in the business, as you pointed out, and I think we are about $350 million now, down $100 million or $150 million from the peak.
componenttext: Meanwhile, we're reducing the investment in the business, as you pointed out, and I think we are about $350 million now, down $100 million or $150 million from the peak.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The balance that we have seen in Asia in the second half of this year, I think, has really just kind of underscored the potential on that region over time. I just would like to get your thoughts about sort of expansion plans in the region, how you would g
componenttext: The balance that we have seen in Asia in the second half of this year, I think, has really just kind of underscored the potential on that region over time. I just would like to get your thoughts about sort of expansion plans in the region, how you would grow, whether it's to go in with the existing partners, or whether you'd greenfield things, and just how important that is to you over the next five or 10 years.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right. It is one of the areas where we see lots of people and not many cans. We've been in China for a long time and we're doing very well there now. We stepped up and bought our partner -- buying our partner out there in one of the p
componenttext: Well, I think you're right. It is one of the areas where we see lots of people and not many cans. We've been in China for a long time and we're doing very well there now. We stepped up and bought our partner -- buying our partner out there in one of the plants as we talked about earlier. John, you might comment -- I mean, we are, at the present time, formulating a strategy for Asia. And it could include those things that you mentioned, working with existing partners on our own. I think if you can find existing assets, particularly in new markets that are operating, and you feel that that's a good way to enter, that might be the best way. But why don't you comment too, John?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been spending a lot of time in that region, and for competitive and other purposes, I won't go into great detail. But we do see a lot of good opportunity. Our strategy to date really has been focused on China, and we're looking at now non-China
componenttext: Yes, we've been spending a lot of time in that region, and for competitive and other purposes, I won't go into great detail. But we do see a lot of good opportunity. Our strategy to date really has been focused on China, and we're looking at now non-China Asia. And as Dave mentioned, when we've had a lot of success, it's typically not by billion that [ph] will come to working with customers, it's potentially acquiring other parties and doing some things like that on a small scale. And so those are the types of things that we're focusing on as priority number one.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you all bought Metal Container, you were -- I think Ray had mentioned that you saw the first year free cash flow at about $50 million, and it sounds like you might be a little bit ahead of that. And I know it may be tough to measure as you're putting
componenttext: When you all bought Metal Container, you were -- I think Ray had mentioned that you saw the first year free cash flow at about $50 million, and it sounds like you might be a little bit ahead of that. And I know it may be tough to measure as you're putting everything together, but would a $55 million or $60 million kind of number be more realistic given what you've experienced so far?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we think we're on track with our original projections.
componenttext: No, we think we're on track with our original projections.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Even though you said earlier that you thought you were doing better than expected with that?
componenttext: Even though you said earlier that you thought you were doing better than expected with that?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the earnings start showing up a little quicker than what we initially anticipated, but I think we're on track for where we hoped we would be. And the full year run rate looks to be where thought it would be when we acquired the business.
componenttext: If the earnings start showing up a little quicker than what we initially anticipated, but I think we're on track for where we hoped we would be. And the full year run rate looks to be where thought it would be when we acquired the business.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing that I'll add into that is, as part of the $50 million in cash flow, we had certain expectations about capital expenditures. As we've gotten into these plants and realized how terrific they were from an overall up peak [ph] perspective, we
componenttext: The only thing that I'll add into that is, as part of the $50 million in cash flow, we had certain expectations about capital expenditures. As we've gotten into these plants and realized how terrific they were from an overall up peak [ph] perspective, we may have a little bit of upside on the CapEx, but again, it's not wholesale.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then thinking about your flexibility or what you choose to do with your free cash, obviously, you took on a little bit more with the Chinese investment later in the year. And I guess looking with an eye on the ratings agencies, does that mean it's lik
componenttext: And then thinking about your flexibility or what you choose to do with your free cash, obviously, you took on a little bit more with the Chinese investment later in the year. And I guess looking with an eye on the ratings agencies, does that mean it's likely you'll go beyond that $250 million payments you owe this year and try to pay off a little more debt and therefore, wait until next year before you would look to do something like a buyback, or should we not read that into your situation?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll have the $250 million in payments, and then we have a lot of flexibility with the extra cash that we're going to generate. I don't think -- by the end of 2010, our credit stats will be better than there right now, and I think there's p
componenttext: Well, I think we'll have the $250 million in payments, and then we have a lot of flexibility with the extra cash that we're going to generate. I don't think -- by the end of 2010, our credit stats will be better than there right now, and I think there's plenty of flexibility to start repurchasing shares and dividends and all the things that we do with the cash.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: During 2010?
componenttext: During 2010?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the Food Can business, obviously, last year was a great year because of some of the inventory situations. But as you look at beyond that and you look at industry pricing and volumes, what do you -- I guess you we can't count on a pack lik
componenttext: When you look at the Food Can business, obviously, last year was a great year because of some of the inventory situations. But as you look at beyond that and you look at industry pricing and volumes, what do you -- I guess you we can't count on a pack like we had in '09, but does the pricing dynamic seem to be similar when you x out the inventory gains in the margin dynamics? Do you see any deterioration or improvement in '10 versus '09?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, at stripping that out, we don't see a lot of deviation in terms of price cost. Think about 12 month ago and what we were going through in terms of having to push through this extraordinary costs. The costs have abated and so it's a much more, I'
componenttext: You know, at stripping that out, we don't see a lot of deviation in terms of price cost. Think about 12 month ago and what we were going through in terms of having to push through this extraordinary costs. The costs have abated and so it's a much more, I'll call it normalized situation, but we don't see any significant issues up or down.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're doing our best to hold the line with our suppliers and to not be in that position that we have in the last couple of years as far as our pricing actions.
componenttext: We're doing our best to hold the line with our suppliers and to not be in that position that we have in the last couple of years as far as our pricing actions.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alton Stump with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alton Stump with Longbow Research.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just looking at the Eastern European bev can market, you mentioned that you saw overall demand conditions stabilize in the fourth quarter. Is there any signs of an actual recovery there yet or are we still a quarter or two away from that?
componenttext: I'm just looking at the Eastern European bev can market, you mentioned that you saw overall demand conditions stabilize in the fourth quarter. Is there any signs of an actual recovery there yet or are we still a quarter or two away from that?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's pretty mature to talk about significant recovery in -- and that's why I've said we have indefinitely put on hold our Lublin, Poland plant because a couple of percent increase doesn't really create the need to start up a new plant. And so unti
componenttext: I think it's pretty mature to talk about significant recovery in -- and that's why I've said we have indefinitely put on hold our Lublin, Poland plant because a couple of percent increase doesn't really create the need to start up a new plant. And so until we see a meaningful, sustainable recovery, you should expect that's what we'll do.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Ruschmeier with Barclay Capital (sic) [Barclays Capital].
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Ruschmeier with Barclay Capital (sic) [Barclays Capital].

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was surprised by your Aerospace revenues, and I was curious if you could elaborate on the backlog you're seeing. You mentioned the antenna Business, how big is backlog and what kind of visibility much you have for '10?
componenttext: I was surprised by your Aerospace revenues, and I was curious if you could elaborate on the backlog you're seeing. You mentioned the antenna Business, how big is backlog and what kind of visibility much you have for '10?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that qualitatively. 12 months ago or 14 months ago, as we were going into 2009, we knew it would be very difficult. And part of the reason why is the number of bids we had outstanding was literally in one of our -- in the harbor side of our
componenttext: Let me answer that qualitatively. 12 months ago or 14 months ago, as we were going into 2009, we knew it would be very difficult. And part of the reason why is the number of bids we had outstanding was literally in one of our -- in the harbor side of our business, literally in the tens of millions of dollars. As we sit here right now, it's approaching a billion of dollars. So as a result, the tone and tenure is much good. Now we haven't won any of that, and that's why we said we have a lot of bids outstanding, and we expect them to win during the course of 2010, that should set us up nicely for growth as we go into the back half of 2010 and 2011 even if, on a probabilistic basis, we win our normal share.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to clarify, in the Metal Beverage Europe, I thought the results were quite strong. You mentioned fix costs removal. What was the fixed cost removal that you were able to achieve and how much more much you have on the docket?
componenttext: I wanted to clarify, in the Metal Beverage Europe, I thought the results were quite strong. You mentioned fix costs removal. What was the fixed cost removal that you were able to achieve and how much more much you have on the docket?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well it was -- as we're going through downtime, we were just putting a particular emphasis on where we're spending our money in the plants. The plants did a very good jobs. As we all know, the trends of volumes got better over time and when you get overti
componenttext: Well it was -- as we're going through downtime, we were just putting a particular emphasis on where we're spending our money in the plants. The plants did a very good jobs. As we all know, the trends of volumes got better over time and when you get overtime, you can get better efficiencies through the plant, and I think that's what we saw. Recall, the year-over-year comparison in the fourth quarter 2008 was quite a challenging one. That's when the economics crisis hit and we have a lot of extra downtime as result of that. So I think it's as much of a comparable basis year-over-year than anything else.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was curious if -- maybe Scott you could remind us on, as we think about debt translation effects for currency, can you remind us the composition of debt as you have roughly by FX exposure?
componenttext: I was curious if -- maybe Scott you could remind us on, as we think about debt translation effects for currency, can you remind us the composition of debt as you have roughly by FX exposure?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The impact year-over-year from a currency translation impact was not significant. In terms of the total debt, we've got -- $320 million of it is in euros, Canada is $78 million and the rest is in U.S.
componenttext: The impact year-over-year from a currency translation impact was not significant. In terms of the total debt, we've got -- $320 million of it is in euros, Canada is $78 million and the rest is in U.S.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to hear if you could give us just an update on that progress on the new Brazil can line, how that start-up is going and when you see a full contribution.
componenttext: I wanted to hear if you could give us just an update on that progress on the new Brazil can line, how that start-up is going and when you see a full contribution.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We actually -- some of us traveled to Brazil early in December and had a chance to go see the plant. It's North of Rio, in the Tres Rio's vicinity. And it's an excellent facility. It's large, it could accommodate three lines when it's fully utilized. But
componenttext: We actually -- some of us traveled to Brazil early in December and had a chance to go see the plant. It's North of Rio, in the Tres Rio's vicinity. And it's an excellent facility. It's large, it could accommodate three lines when it's fully utilized. But right now, the new line that was installed had the best start up that we've ever had in any can plant. And the day after we were there, they made two million cans, and they made money in the second month, I guess, of operations. So it's just doing very, very well, sold out, and the customers are just up the road. It's good, good situation. John, you were there and Ray. Do you. . .

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: From an earnings contribution, as we all know, David mentioned of it that built three lines. And when you really start to get to the operating leverage, that's when the second line goes. So I think, yes we are in the black, which is good news. But I think
componenttext: From an earnings contribution, as we all know, David mentioned of it that built three lines. And when you really start to get to the operating leverage, that's when the second line goes. So I think, yes we are in the black, which is good news. But I think of the trajectory of their earnings as we sell that line out and begin to think about additional capacity, I think that's where the leverage really comes in.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just given the current growth rate of the market, can you give us any kind of flavor or prediction when you might be able to get that second line going there?
componenttext: And just given the current growth rate of the market, can you give us any kind of flavor or prediction when you might be able to get that second line going there?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking actively because we believe with the day growth of the market as we sit here right now, the market is going to be very tight in terms of cans, soon.
componenttext: We're looking actively because we believe with the day growth of the market as we sit here right now, the market is going to be very tight in terms of cans, soon.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly is if you could just give us an update on the acquisition of a Chinese JV that you're looking at in terms of any updates in terms of timing or what you're hearing.
componenttext: And then lastly is if you could just give us an update on the acquisition of a Chinese JV that you're looking at in terms of any updates in terms of timing or what you're hearing.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are going through the process, the antitrust process, and we're hopeful that we can close sometime early in the second quarter.
componenttext: We are going through the process, the antitrust process, and we're hopeful that we can close sometime early in the second quarter.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Richard Skidmore with Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up, John, on your comments with regarding the renegotiation of contracts at North America. headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: I'd prefer not to go into any detail because this -- nothing else were abound by confidentiality. But as I reiterated in my prepared remarks, the conversations were constructive and we were able to have good discussions with our customers and we're satisfied with the result.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Shifting then to your commentary about North American volume, will it be any footprint rationalization that comes out of the down volume in 2010?
componenttext: Shifting then to your commentary about North American volume, will it be any footprint rationalization that comes out of the down volume in 2010?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No long-term -- as you know, we've gone through the last couple of years of taking a real hard look at our capacity footprint. We've taken effect on -- we're out unfortunately, but it was the right thing to do long-term for the business. And as we sit her
componenttext: No long-term -- as you know, we've gone through the last couple of years of taking a real hard look at our capacity footprint. We've taken effect on -- we're out unfortunately, but it was the right thing to do long-term for the business. And as we sit here today, we have no expectations going forward of doing anything else in the near-term.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The can plant closures that you did last year, I know that you had mentioned shipping some volumes. Is that contract now done and you're no longer shipping the volumes up to the Northwest from California, I believe, in such that you'll see that benefits o
componenttext: The can plant closures that you did last year, I know that you had mentioned shipping some volumes. Is that contract now done and you're no longer shipping the volumes up to the Northwest from California, I believe, in such that you'll see that benefits of those costs savings coming through in 2010?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you tell me how much of the pension expense was in the pension funding this year? Last year, it was 80 and 73?
componenttext: Could you tell me how much of the pension expense was in the pension funding this year? Last year, it was 80 and 73?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The expense last year was about $74 million. This year, it will be about $79 million. On the funding side, as I made my comments earlier, we pre-funded some payments, or made some additional payments in 2009, so our total worldwide pension funding was jus
componenttext: The expense last year was about $74 million. This year, it will be about $79 million. On the funding side, as I made my comments earlier, we pre-funded some payments, or made some additional payments in 2009, so our total worldwide pension funding was just under $120 million, and it will drop in 2010 to under $80 million.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: I just want to comeback to Europe, it sounds like, I think in answering Chris' question, you still expected European EBIT to be up in '10 due to cost. And currency, I just want to confirm that. And to the point of maybe some price compression or margin compression, I just wanted to extend possible on this form dig into that. Obviously, you have contracts with some form of passer. You said that you were relatively tight in terms of supply and demand. So I was just wondering what would it be that you'd see some compression going in to 2010.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is John, maybe I'll take a first step. First, to your question on the [indiscernible] do we expect a year-over-year earnings improvement in Europe? Yes we do. Two, in terms of the price cost compression. It's a very competitive world out there. And a
componenttext: This is John, maybe I'll take a first step. First, to your question on the [indiscernible] do we expect a year-over-year earnings improvement in Europe? Yes we do. Two, in terms of the price cost compression. It's a very competitive world out there. And as we were going into 2010, we didn't have much business up for renewal but we did have some business. And when you have a supply-demand situation, that's a little bit more challenging than in the past. Economics 101 holds true, but we want to be very close to our customers and we're certainly not in the business of gaining share at all, but we haven't been putting capacity in so we're just keeping our capacity running. But we did experience a little bit more pricing issues, I think, as a result of the supply-demand issue.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: If you do hit the $500 million or greater bogey for free cash flow in 2010 that's, obviously, a greater treatment for the company, it's only based on history. As you think about the future and putting growth aside, what areas might you need to reinvest in '11 and '12? Said differently, how sustainable do you think a free cash flow level in the $400 million to $500 million level is the first portion of this decade?

componenttext: I think the cash flow statement -- until we see growth -- I mentioned that CapEx would stay at fairly controlled levels until we see growth returning, so I would see our free cash flow to be pretty strong out in the next few years, absent growth opportunities.

Some of the adjustments that we'd made, the new lines in Europe and so forth, we put the clutch in on that for now. Frankly, the two markets that are reeling well are Brazil and China. Brazil because it's currently 50% owned, it doesn't show up in our numbers except as a line in equity and earnings. But there is investment going on there, but. . .

componenttext: One thing -- Gee, I don't know. I think we've got and we're going to continue to execute as we are. I don't feel that there is much threatening us. But we're pretty focused, we feel like we've got the business in hand, not a lot of discussion today about contracts, it maybe up. To [ph] answer that, we're pretty well loaded and ready to roll.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Hoover, Chairman and CEO of Ball Corporation. Pl
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Ball Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Hoover, Chairman and CEO of Ball Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Suzy, and good morning, everybody. This is Ball Corporation's Conference Call regarding our first quarter 2010 results. The information to be provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes ma
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Suzy, and good morning, everybody. This is Ball Corporation's Conference Call regarding our first quarter 2010 results. The information to be provided during this call will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results or outcomes may differ materially from those that may be expressed or implied. Some factors that could cause the results or outcomes to differ in the company's latest 10-Q and other company SEC filings, as well as company news releases. And if you don't already have our earnings release, it is available on our website at www.ball.com. Information regarding the use of non-GAAP financial measures may also be found on our website. Joining me today on the call is John Hayes, Ball's President and Chief Operating Officer; and Scott Morrison, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In a moment, Scott will provide key financial metrics for the quarter and for 2010, and John will follow with details about our operating performance. 
While we reported strong first quarter results against some difficult comparisons last year when we had a net inventory holding gain in the range of $35 million. And also, as we described in our press release, we're seeing signs of growth in our packaging markets, which is very welcome. And during the quarter, our Aerospace segment saw an improving contract to work environment. We did announce earlier this month a new contract called GFO-2 [Geosat Follow-on 2 ] with significant potential and we're glad to see that begin to come in. So we hope to hear more about other proposals in that part of our business soon. And with that, Scott?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. In the first quarter, Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share were at $0.85, well ahead of last year's $0.77. Drivers during the quarter were positive contributions from the four acquired beverage can plants in the fourth quarter of las
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. In the first quarter, Ball's comparable diluted earnings per share were at $0.85, well ahead of last year's $0.77. Drivers during the quarter were positive contributions from the four acquired beverage can plants in the fourth quarter of last year: Volume improvements in our packaging businesses, very good operating performance and cost controls, tax benefits realized on a foreign investment in Asia and a strong start in equity earnings in affiliates in Brazil and further strengthening expected during the remaining quarters of this year. These were offset somewhat by higher interest costs due to the acquisition financing from last year. 
Aerospace segment first quarter earnings were down slightly on lower revenue. As mentioned on the last conference call, the trends in this business appear to be improving. While contract wins, including the one noted in the earnings release, will likely not have a significant impact on 2010, they do firm up staffing in the business and set us up nicely going into 2011.
Turning to some key financial metrics, interest expense in the quarter was up as expected due to the acquisition financing from last year's purchase of the four Metal Beverage plants. While we still expect full year interest expense to be in the range of $140 million, excluding the impacts of the one-time interest costs associated with calling of the 2012 notes. 
The first quarter effective tax rate of 20% was favorably impacted by certain foreign tax benefits earned on investments. As you are aware, the recognition of tax benefits tends to be a lumpy activity. We continue to expect the full year rate to be in the range of 32%. But our tax department historically has done a great job of finding opportunities. 
The company's receivables securitization program is now being recorded as a balance sheet obligation, due to the effects of the accounting pronouncement I described in the January call. The impact for the quarter was an increase in accounts receivable of $250 million and an increase in debt. While the net balance sheet and total cash flow effect is zero, there was a one-time reduction in operating cash flow for the amount of receivables securitized and an offsetting increase in cash inflows from financing activities. This change has been broken out as separate line items in the press release financials, as you can see the net change and comparability between periods. 
During the quarter, we raised $500 million in new 6.75% notes due in 2020. On April 21, we used the proceeds of the new notes to retire $509 million and 6 7/8% notes due in 2012. Because of the timing of the new note issuance and the calling of the existing notes, our balance sheet reflects both debt issues and considerable cash on hand at the end of the quarter. The 2012 notes that were retired are shown as short-term debt at quarter end. 
Also following January's earnings conference call, we announced the repurchase of $125 million of our stock through an accelerated share repurchase program. The program resulted in the delivery of 90% or 2.2 million shares on the execution day with the remainder to be delivered at the conclusion of the contract, which will occur during the next few months. Given our significant free cash flow expectations for 2010 which continue to be in excess of $500 million, we will increase the size of the share repurchase program during 2010. As always, we look to return value to shareholders through a combination of share repurchases and dividends. During the period that our accelerated share repurchase contract remains open, it is cumbersome to change the current dividend amount, but we continue to evaluate both of these mechanisms to ensure that we have the right mix. 
With that, I'll turn it over to John.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. Ball delivered a strong first quarter.  Global consumers appeared to be getting back on track.  And that, along with balancing our supply and demand in our metal packaging businesses and very good and improving operating performance, makes
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. Ball delivered a strong first quarter.  Global consumers appeared to be getting back on track.  And that, along with balancing our supply and demand in our metal packaging businesses and very good and improving operating performance, makes us optimistic as we head into the busy summer selling season. 
Profitability for the quarter of our metal beverage packaging, Americas and Asia segment met our expectations and was notably improved over first quarter 2009. This was driven largely by the impact of the newly acquired U.S. plants and the lack of inventory holding losses recorded last year. Cost savings from prior plant rationalizations also contributed to improved results. Our CSD customers are fine-tuning the value versus volume equation, which is beginning to show up in the improving sequential CSD can volume trends in the first quarter. 
In China, both the overall market as well as Ball saw double-digit volume growth rates in the quarter. Herbal teas and beer demand were the main catalyst behind the volume improvement. In Brazil, the startup of our new facility continues to go very well and it is sold out. We announced the addition of a second line in this facility and it should come on stream in early 2011. The market is performing very well. It's up mid-teens, and we continue to look for opportunities while remaining disciplined.
We continue to expect 2010 profitability in the Americas and Asia segment to be improved. Driven by the contribution of three additional quarters of the acquisition that closed in October, cost savings resulted from the previously announced capacity closures. Our relentless focus on our cost optimization and best practice sharing activities continued growth from new innovative product launches like our 90-calorie mini soft drink can, improved penetration of the can into the Kraft brewing segment and improving volume trends in both the U.S. and China.
In our European operations, volumes were up mid single-digit percent in the first quarter led by promising growth in both Western and Eastern Europe that was slightly offset by weaker export sales. Continued cost savings at the plant level also contributed to improved results. As in the Americas and Asia segment, we expect earnings improvement, albeit on a euro basis in 2010 in this segment. The business is beginning to prepare for World Cup promotional activities, so we'll wait to see how much of a positive impact this will have with our customers. 
And Food and Household products segment continues to execute well. Volumes were up slightly above 3% in the quarter and many of our customers are off to a nice start. First year, year-over-year performance was down due to the lack of inventory holding gains recorded last year that Dave mentioned. However, even with that difficult comparison, the business had a very solid quarter due largely to excellent operating performance. While food and aerosol can volumes have rebounded, they are not yet back to historical levels. Continued volume growth and our disciplined approach to commercial activities offers upside for the remainder of this year and into 2011.
Plastic packaging, Americas challenges continue. Lower volumes in the cold-fill CSD and water segments and manufacturing disruptions at a PVT plant due to a customer qualification occurrence led to an operating loss in the quarter. The manufacturing disruption is behind us and plants are catching up with the recent increased demand at the C store level. Also the food specialty plastic side of the business is seeing improved trends from our customer base. Ball Aerospace experienced somewhat softer sales in EBIT in the quarter, but also saw progress in contract integrations and, more importantly, new awards. This trend, if it continues, may provide a foundation for better results. Our antenna components and services businesses are maintaining good growth trajectory, and the hardware side of this business also has some glimmers of future contracts awards. So stay tuned here. 
Company-wide, our operations are executing well in what appears to be the beginning of an improved global environment. Continued discipline around capital spending and working capital reductions will ensure the delivery of significant free cash flow, which is a major focus in 2010.
During the past two years, we've taken numerous actions to improve performance in a difficult global environment while also positioning Ball for growth when the economy improves. Though we are not done with that process, in fact we're never done, we do like where we stand today with our manufacturing footprint and the leverage we can poll to grow as markets grow. Dave?

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you, Scott for your comments. While this year is only a third over now and we reported only the first quarter of it, we're experiencing building momentum and general improvement in our markets. For the full year, we cont
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you, Scott for your comments. While this year is only a third over now and we reported only the first quarter of it, we're experiencing building momentum and general improvement in our markets. 
For the full year, we continue to expect the company's 2010 earnings to be above those of 2009. We're focused in pushing hard for improved results in cash flow. We've taken steps in our operations to improve profitability and position Ball for continued organic growth, as well as opportunities in developing markets. The balance sheet has been strengthened and we have additional flexibility as we evaluate the best ways to create significant value for all of our shareholders. 
And with that, Suzy, we're ready for questions.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question coming from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, it gets a little bit difficult because as part of the acquisition, we're moving volumes in the system, so what was legacy and what were some of the formal metal containers. But as best we can tell in the legacy businesses, it was down low- to mid-si
componenttext: Yeah, it gets a little bit difficult because as part of the acquisition, we're moving volumes in the system, so what was legacy and what were some of the formal metal containers. But as best we can tell in the legacy businesses, it was down low- to mid-single digits. And in the non legacy or the former Metal Container plants, the volume was quite strong. Recall at the end of the year, we talked about a slight step back in 2010. We're seeing a lot of promotional activity from our customers right now. And so as we go into the busy summer selling months, I think we have some good momentum, not only on the CSD side but also on the beer side, where we're seeing more promotional activity in that segment as well.

headline: Ball Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
